## Worries

## It's social media's fault! ???

:::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
- Algorithms radicalize people
- Echo chambers cause polarization

### Solutions?
:::
::: {.column width="40%"}
![](https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2014/04/03/10/53/spiral-311612_1280.png){width="150"}
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/YouTube_Logo_2017.svg/1920px-YouTube_Logo_2017.svg.png){width="200"}
<!-- ![](images/Guess2023_algorithm_effects.svg) -->
:::
::::

- [Dissolve](https://www.pnas.org/content/115/37/9216) echo chambers & [turn off](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abp9364) algorithms

::: fragment

### The Science:

![](images/google_election_fraud.png){.absolute bottom=230 right=0 width="750"}

- People [look for](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06078-5) radical [content](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2101967118).
- No algorithm effects on opinions & emotions (studies [1](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w), [2](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abp9364), [3](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.add8424))
- Echo chambers are [larger offline](https://doi.org/10.1093/qje/qjr044), reducing them [backfires](https://www.pnas.org/content/115/37/9216).
:::

::: footer
Robertson et al., [2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06078-5); Hosseinmardi et al., [2024](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2313377121); 
Munger & Philipps, [2022](https://doi.org/10.1177/1940161220964767); <br>
Nyhan et al., [2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w); 
Guess et al., [2023](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abp9364);
Guess et al., [2023](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.add8424);
Bail et al. [2018](https://www.pnas.org/content/115/37/9216);
Gentzkow & Shapiro, [2011](https://doi.org/10.1093/qje/qjr044)
:::

::: notes
- I know this sounds like I don't think there's any problem, which is not true either. 
- I just want to make the point that misinformation (manipulation) is overestimated, it's never a good idea to assume people are stupid, and that not everything is social media's fault. 
- I'll leave you hanging in suspense about what I think the actual role of social media is, you'll have to check out our website, a podcast I did recently, or watch Doc dok 1 on ORF next Friday. 
:::

## Digital Echo Chambers & Filter Bubbles

::: columns
::: {.column width="30%"}
![](https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2017/01/13/19/40/family-1978106_1280.png)
:::

::: {.column width="70%"}
-   Echo chambers: offline [stronger](https://doi.org/10.1093/qje/qjr044) than online
-   [Magnitude](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w) varies greatly
    -   **20.6%** of Facebook users: **75%** of posts from like-minded sources
    -   **23.1%**: less than **25%** of posts
-   Algorithms: smaller (6%) & much less [influence](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.aaa1160) than the social network
-   [Groups & Pages](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.ade7138): highly segregated
:::
:::

::: footer
Gentzkow & Shapiro, [2011](https://doi.org/10.1093/qje/qjr044); Bakshy et al. [2015](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.aaa1160); Nyhan et al., [2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w); Gonzalez-Bailon et al., [2023](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.ade7138)
:::

::: notes
-   Exposure to different perspectives online echo chamber, gap between Conservative/Liberal in visiting conservative sites: (7.5%, Gentzkow Shapiro 2011), Gonzalez Bailon: 35%
-   Difference between Rep./Dem. for Rep. content (USA): [7.5%](https://doi.org/10.1093/qje/qjr044)-[35%](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.ade7138)
:::

## Influence of Algorithms

Facebook [study](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w): Down-ranking of like-minded posts

![](images/Nyhan_2023.svg)

::: footer
Nyhan et al., [2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w)
:::

## Algorithm: Down-Ranking Like-Minded Sources

![](images/Nyhan_2023_results_Fig3_a_d.svg){.r-stretch}

-   Similar findings in 2 more studies: <br> [No Algorithm](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abp9364) or [No Re-Shares](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.add8424)

::: footer
Nyhan et al., [2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w); Guess et al., [2023](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abp9364); Guess et al., [2023](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.add8424)
:::

::: notes
Profanity etc. Reduction: from 0.034% to 0.030% for content with slur words, from 3.15% to 2.81% for uncivil content, from 0.76% to 0.55% for content from misinformation repeat offenders
:::

## Algorithms & Radicalization Spirals?

-   Influence of [Google's Algorithm](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06078-5) on results: search terms have a much stronger effect

![](images/google.png)

-   YouTube: Algorithm leads to [less radical consumption](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2313377121)
-   Clicks for radical videos: from [outside the platform](https://doi.org/10.1177/1940161220964767)
-   [User preferences](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2101967118) determine views of radical videos

$\rightarrow$ Users actively seek like-minded content

::: footer
Robertson et al., [2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06078-5); Hosseinmardi et al., [2024](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2313377121); Hosseinmardi et al., [2021](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2101967118); Munger & Philipps, [2022](https://doi.org/10.1177/1940161220964767)
:::

## So what?

- Reducing misinformation will not solve the real problems 
- [Alarmist narrative](https://doi.org/10.1007/s11109-024-09911-3) reduces trust in reliable news
- Misinformation & social media companies are scapegoats to avoid doing **the hard work**

## Myth 4: Misinformation drives behavior

:::: columns
::: {.column width="81%"}
- Strong effects on opinions and behavior.

### Solutions?

- Reduce it, facts, warning, inoculations etc.

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
### The Science:

- Russian disinformation attacks during 2016 Trump election: no effects on attitudes, polarization & voting (study [1](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-022-35576-9), [2](https://www.pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.1906420116))

### Misinformation myths

-   People are gullible
-   Emotions make people irrational
-   People are exposed to a lot of misinformation
-   Misinformation has strong effects on behavior
-   Algorithms radicalize people
-   Echo chambers cause the problem

### Truth

- It's hard to change people's minds
- Emotions are functional
- Misinformation (and news) exposure are low
- Persuasion has very small effects
- Algorithms are not an all round solution
- Dissolving echo chambers causes polarization

### Wrong solutions

- reduce misinformation 
- reduce emotions
- make people more skeptical
- reduce echo chambers
:::
